description.text: My old MacBook Pro's battery is almost dead. So I need to keep power connector always on to prevent shutdown. So I make a holder to lock the MagSafe on my Mac. This MagLock is inspired by MagStay (http://www.thoughtout.biz/products/MagStay-PRO.html) It will prevent Mac MagSafe Power connector accidently disconnect. The MagStay will occupy one USB port which makes it less practical to use. So, I come up with MagLock which allow me to use the USB port next to the power connector.
Print with no extra shell and 65% fill. Bore the LED hole if necessary.

title: Shopping Cart Token/Coin w. Paper Clip

description.text:
I'm old fashioned and keep my grocery list on paper and I've never found a good place to keep my paper while shopping. Since I couldn't find any solution on Thingiverse I whipped this up, a combined shopping cart token and paper clip/holder.

For this thing to be usable in other countries than Sweden I made it customizable so that any coin can be replicated. Click on the "Open in Customizer" button or download the scad file and open it in OpenSCAD. Before making a customized version though, take a look under the remix section to see if there is one already made for your coin.

You'll need a screw to complete this thing, size and length is customizable (I've been using an M3x16mm)

Velleman Vertex K8400

title: Assignment 10: "Creating New Industries" - Apple Keyboard Keycaps

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0cWxqpHLv3k

Use computer generated design data to create enclosures for Apple devices

3D printing can be quicker and less expensive than machining of prototype parts or production of cast or molded parts by conventional techniques (which can take from a few weeks to several months, depending on the complexity of the part)

One application of 3D printing is production of parts such as enclosures for consumer electronics.

Parts for consumer electronics may have small sizes, tight constraints on their dimensions and complex shapes, which can make traditional subtractive manufacturing method difficult or expensive.

As a Technical Advisor in Apple’s Technical Support team, AppleCare, my job is to isolate the root cause of any issue a customer’s device is experiencing down to hardware or software; If the issue relates to software, I am expected to resolve the issue; If it relates to hardware, I am expected to refer the customer to an Apple Retail Store or Authorized Service Provider for hardware services.

Most often, if the issue is isolated down to a fault with the hardware, the next question I am asked is how much we should expect the repair to cost. Of course, this is a complex question that requires a subjective answer mainly based upon: parts, availability of parts, and labor costs (which include validating and confirming the root of the issue as well as physically replacing any damaged components)

At times, I have more technically savvy customers who have replaced components in their Apple Devices without the help of professional and are simply calling to inquire about how/where to purchase replacement components for their device. When I make a recommendation on where they should purchase these components, I always consider two main factors in my answer: affordability and reliability.

If the components are available to purchase on Apple’s website, I will direct them there, but often times there are internal components like keycap replacements, Graphics Cards, Processors, etc. that we no longer offer online (especially for obsolete/vintage products.) In these cases, I generally try to locate the parts on a service provider’s website and refer them there.

If Apple were to supply advisors in AppleCare and technicians in the Retail Division with a database of computer generated design data of replacement components for every Apple device manufactured, we could significantly cut repair costs and improve turn-around times for repair.

I thought it could be gradually integrated into Apple’s repair process, starting small with some of the more common, minor hardware issues such as missing keyboard keys, home/side buttons for iOS devices, adaptors for notebook computers with missing ports, converters for traveling, stylus for touch screen devices

EXAMPLE:
For any missing keyboard key, searching by model number, obtain 3d printed design data for:

  1. the KeyCap : This is the piece of plastic that has the letter on it.
  2. the Hinge (retainer clip): The plastic or metal scissor clip pieces that hold the key cap to the base of the keyboard. (there are different Type clips for different models of Apple labtops)
  3. the Cup : This is the piece of rubber or plastic that acts as the spring to rebound the key after your press it.
    Getting a key replaced at the retail store or any service provider can run upwards of $60 for replacement parts and 85$ for labor.
    If you order these parts online from 3rd party providers, they often run around 3.95 – 5.95 per key, not including shipping costs.

If these parts were at the hands of customers who are able to carry out their own DIY repairs and at the hands of technicians in store or in AppleCare, these parts could be printed quickly (reducing repair time) and at a much cheaper cost (avoiding shipping in replacement parts the store doesn’t have readily available), thus reducing repair costs and turn-around time for repairs overall.

Because the type of material and the dimensions of the completed part must be consistent with the materials used to manufacture the original parts for that specific model, I think it would be most effective to supply these to technicians to reduce repair costs, but also to customers comfortable with doing a DIY repair, providing a simple process to generate the data for the part, and allowing them to either print the part themselves or have the file printed at a nearby service provider/retail store.

If Apple were to provide these parts online, offering a repair service center components database in which the customer finds the correct model and 3d print files for their device by searching for their serial number will ensure that the correct replacement parts are printed every time.

What are BMGs? (Bulk Solidifying Amorphous Alloys)

BMG = Bulk Metallic Glasses/Bulk-solidifying amorphous alloys
(aka the technical term for Liquidmetal alloy)

  • Recently developed class of metallic materials
  • May be solidified and cooled at relatively slow rates
  • At Room Temperature:

    retain amorphous, non-crystalline (i.e. glassy) state
    Amorphous State: highly advantageous for certain applications (electronic components, medical devices, etc.)

Solidification & Cooling Process for BMG Materials:
amorphous state - produced by rapid cooling
crystalline state - produced by slow cooling

Risk of Partial Crystallization in the Solidification & Cooling Process:

  • one risk with creation of bulk amorphous alloy parts is partial crystallization due to either slow cooling or impurities in the raw material; i.e. if cooling rate is not sufficiently high, crystals can form inside the alloy during the cooling process so that the benefits of the amorphous state are partially or completely lost

(Source: Apple's Patent LAYER-BY-LAYER CONSTRUCTION WITH BULK METALLIC GLASSES http://www.google.com/patents/US20130309121)

Limitations of Pre-existing Methods for Processing BMG Materials

Developing Amorphous Alloy Systems

  • Until the 90's, processability of BMG's was a lot more limited (amorphous alloys available in powder form or in very thin foils or strips with very small critical thickness (less than 100 micrometers))
  • Since the 90s more amorphous alloy systems developed based upon different elements with much lower critical cooling rates
  • Since they have much lower critical cooling rates, they also have much larger critical casting thicknesses
Shaping Amorphous Alloy Systems into Structural Components

New Method using 3D Printing:

  • New methods developed for casting BMG parts having a controlled amorphicity are needed (high degree of amorphicity and low degree of crystallinity)
  • Apples Patent for Constructing a Part from BMG Powder (layer by layer)
    Using a layer of BMG powder capable of being fused to other layers through laser electron beam heating to arrive at the desired shape in an amorphous state suitable for internal and external components of electronics. (i.e. Keyboard Keys)
Apple Inc.,. (2016). Layer-by-layer construction with bulk metallic glasses. United States. (http://www.google.com/patents/US20130309121)

author: anacastillejo

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0gjTarEbTIN

print_settings.Notes:: I set it to 0% infill but with 10 bottom & top layers with 10 shells. I don't feel they are heavy enough and if I reprint I would go for 50 shells to add some weight which makes them near solid.  However, given the potential bruising the lighter ones I made will suffice.  I used Nylon, see below.

description.text:
Inspired by popular toy back in the 70s. My mother introduced these to me at a young age and now I want to pass this gem on to my kiddos.

Select one of the two provided STL files and print a pair. Find a string (shoestring works great) and thread through each ball. The original uses a keyring, but I'll leave that at your discretion how you want to complete the final assembly. I left my string fairly long so I can adjust length as necessary. I may add the holder/handle if there's an interest.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I set it to 0% infill but with 10 bottom & top layers with 10 shells. I don't feel they are heavy enough and if I reprint I would go for 50 shells to add some weight which makes them near solid. However, given the potential bruising the lighter ones I made will suffice. I used Nylon, see below.

I believe they are making a comeback, but I need to warn you they were pulled off the shelves due to the materials at the time had a tendency to explode if you "clacked" them hard enough. (source)

I used Taulman 618 Nylon to provide durability since the material is nearly indestructible. Understand the potential dangers and risks when selecting material.

What a pain to print! I successfully printed at 35mm/s @ 250C, bed @ 45C and I used a 100 line brim. I used zero cooling and kept my printer shields up - curling was a definite issue so I printed with support; however, I provided another STL with support you cut off which should provide better results (bottom is just cosmetic, doesn't impact the performance). For additional adhesion I even taped the brim down!

Well that sucks!! Stay down this time!! Spaghetti is one thing, failures caused by this tests anger management skills!!

comments.text: Nice balls! Do you play with them often?
comments.author: steveweber314

comments.text: Not too often, when they get to swinging it hurts when they bang around where they shouldn't.  I need to get a sack to store them or a strap to hold them out of the way.  You should score some blue filament and makes yourself a set.
comments.author: steveweber314

comments.text: "Spaghetti is one thing, failures caused by this tests anger management skills!!"

title: Stretching Room - Haunted Mansion - Vent Grate

description.text:
"And consider this dismaying observation: This chamber has no windows and no doors, which offers you this chilling challenge: to find a way out!"

Inspired by the classic Disney attraction The Haunted Mansion, this heating grate mimics the ones which adorn the walls of the Stretching Room. Whether the floor is going down or the ceiling is going up, these sinister faces can set the mood in your home now too.

Just size this half grate to the slot you need to fill, print two and creep out your friends and neighbors.

See the originals in the Mansion here:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/faeofdoom/10977803855/

author: TJJohn12

description.text:
All my designs & progress available @ http://marginallyclever.com
As seen on Hackaday.
Stewart Platforms are the machines under flight simulators. They're also used in robotic surgery. They are normally only seen in universities because students have to build custom machines for their specific applications. As part of Raising Robot Literacy I believe making a standardized robot available off the shelf would promote robot use and understanding. I hope you will support me in this endeavour.
This robot is currently missing the java code to make it easy to run. It's not bad
I package and ship this robot as a complete DIY kit. Lead time is currently one week.
Features:
  • Runs on GCODE
  • 1500g static holding force (worst case, tested to failure)
  • 20 degrees pitch & roll
  • 10 degrees yaw
  • +/-40mm heave, surge, & sway
  • Measures 165mm across the top, 230mm across the base, 190mm high at rest, ~230mm at center position
  • Weighs ~1650g. 150g less and it could carry a copy of itself!
  • Very good (<0.005") repeatability
  • Limit switches & homing (G28)
    Mounting holes on top plate have been planned for an extra 7th axis (full yaw rotation).
    If you don't feel like finding all these parts yourself, I can make you a set.
    Arduino code, Bill of Materials, and assembly instructions on Github
Arduino code, Bill of Materials, and assembly instructions on Github The parts are cut from 3mm birch ply.

description.text:
This hand is designed to be used as a robotics platform or be remodeled for use as a prosthetic device.

This design features a rigid yet anatomically accurate arm, elbow and hand. The pads of the fingers are flat so that touch sensation can be added. The forearm is designed so that stepper motors and batteries may be mounted on the flat internal surface. The tendon guides are easily threaded by using a thin wire. Pass the wire through the guides and so that it may be super glued to 100 lb carbon fiber. Fishing line of this description will work well. Once the glue is dry simply pull the wire and the line will thread itself. Superglue the line at the end of the finger tips. File and sand each part to insure that complete freedom and flexibility is attained before you superglue the pins for the joints. The clearance between moving parts is .020 inch so the prints will have less interference and require less sculpting during assembly.

All .ipt files have been uploaded. If you are not an Autodesk Inventor user just convert the files using any of a number of file converters on the internet.

If you have questions you may contact me at [email protected]

Check out Shop Class - https://sites.google.com/site/shopclasscurriculum/?pageId=108179657729010009612

Have fun!

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
Features:
  • Changed belt anchorage to the carriage. Requires 4 screws and 4 nuts less. The number of necessary plastic parts is reduced to 3 pieces. Reduced the size of belt anchorage.
  • Perhaps setting the tension bolt on the right, left or both sides.
  • Instead of plastic parts added to the excluded bend radius limiters belt.
  • Place the fan mount is moved closer to the extruder. Reduced overall size of the carriage. In the primary source for the fan region decreased printing.
  • The fan is mounted on a screw M3, rather than two.
  • Improved the installation location of clamps clamping LM8UU - they do not speak the dimensions of the box. For clamps beneath the gear extruder added notches. Toothed wheel does not touch fasteners. (The previous version of the picture, had to put a nut under the extruder to prevent grazing)
  • Added places to check boxes for the optical limit switches.

• Print this item
  • Drop support for the installation site belt.
  • Remove the support in place of fastening the fan with guide pin.
  • Install nut fan.
  • Set LM8UU, fix their collars.
  • Set the adjuster bolt and nut.
  • Set the extruder.
  • Install the bottom bracket to the printer.
  • Fasten the belt. Establish details of limiting bending radius belt.
  • Tighten the belt.

author: anacastillejo

title: Blowback Rubber band SIG Sauer P320 pistol gun

description.text:
This is in very experimental stage.
Inspired by Blowback Rubber band guns I saw on Youtube,
which were made with wood, which require a lot of woodworking skills.

so I'm attempting 3D printed version.

Pistol model is by "Rabid Beagles" which I found on Sketchup 3D Warehouse.
He (or she, but probably he) has very nice models of many weapons,
https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/by/wujoberto
which are nicely detailed, but not overwhelmingly so, and very cleanly made,
so very easy to work with.

but once I'm done with the internals, probably can be adopted to any slider operated pistols.

comments.text:
Im on same quest. I guess i understood mechanics. Now i want to do a test assembly of parts and turn it 3d printable. May be we can Exchange some info.
Thas what i have until now: https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=80FCCC355A3E93FA!226853&authkey=!AA1TPSjB8cXkSe8&v=3&ithint=photo%2cjpg
Im using designspark mechanical.
comments.author: ProSoft

comments.text:
yes, major difference between my design and what I saw on Youtube, is that the trigger is doing rotational movement,
rather than translation movement.
which makes little room for mechanism right above the trigger area, and below the barrel.
comments.author: ProSoft

comments.text: My main inspiration is here: https://youtu.be/fxsAumI4GMA?t=5m43s
comments.author: Simhopp

comments.text: Neat! Can't wait to try printing one

comments.text: it still has a long way to go.

description.text:
This is like a tinfoil hat for your LG Tribute phone.
Aliens and government conspirators are constantly tapping into your phone's camera, mapping out your daily surroundings. They know whether you roll your toilet paper over or underhanded! They track your facial expressions when you're reading your email or sitting on the throne!
Well those bitches can't see through plastic! This stylish phone topper (and bottomer) will make your phone look like a secret of the ooze, all while covering your phone's cameras. Of course, they slide off quickly enough when you need to take a picture.
Freecad files included in case you want to tweak.

I haven't figured out how to take a picture of this yet, it works that well!

description.text:
I loved the Simple Metal Footprint by Thorped (Thing 593072) that I printed for my Simple Metal, so decided to design one for the Metal Plus keeping the aesthetics similar to Thorped's original design.

I found the Metal Plus to be a bit unstable when the build platform moves to its end-stops, this makes its much more stable and keeps it well grounded.

You just attach it to the printer using the existing screws.

Print the pads in any flexible material for best results.

3D Printing Reviews explains this modification in good detail, and can been seen here:
https://youtu.be/-noalu8BAgA

title: LeGnome! I thought someone had to do that one...

description.text:
Captain Makagnom ready for action!! (if someone can explain me why Thingiverse rotates my pictures...would be great...) The Lego design comes from the excellent Xmas Lego Men from Skimbal (thing:5232). UPDATE: 19/09/13
Here are the final parts, separated, repaired, and ready to print. Use some support for the head.
I place only body, belt, head and hat. For the rest of the parts, go visit the excellent X-mas Men at the source. they are 100% compatible.

Print the body, head, belt and hat.
Go and fetch the rest of the Lego Men at Skimbal X-mas Lego Men (link at the source for my thing). You will need 2 arms, 2 hands and the hips. Also, everything is public on tinkercad.com..just search me: kyoxilbuzz Feel free to modify it (i think the head would still deserve some work at the bottom), and to add some more accessories!! I am mid-way printing the body on my Mendel, and 3/4 of the head on my Rep2. Soon, pictures!!

author: MidnightCassiopeia

description.text:
This is a custom attachment I designed to clip onto the side of my office phone.

It was basically designed to hold a "cheat sheet" of select internal phone numbers for commonly called colleagues. I personally find it easier to hit the "transfer" button and type in the three digit short code than press the address book button and start searching through names/numbers whilst I know someone is effectively waiting on hold.

Still a work in progress, trying to find a secure way to clip the front and back parts together.

Update: 5th version in the iterative design. Thinned out edges for quicker print as well as larger frame for extra information in the "cheat sheet". clip mechanism added to front and back of frame so they "snap" together nicely. Also, clip brackets shortened and angled for better viewing when phone is laying down or standing up.

This is a simple spool holder for RepRap Mendel and Prusa. It's compatible with multiple sizes of spools and makes swapping spool easy. It uses the y-bar-clamp from the default Mendel.

• print out plastic parts ;)
  • cut 4 pieces of threaded rod of the size to your liking. Somewhere between 15 and 25 cm depending on the size of spools you plan to use.
  • cut one piece of smooth rod of about 40 cm
  • put the y-bar-clamp on the upper bars of your RepRap, with the threaded rods
  • put the spoolholder plastics on the threaded rods and put the bearrings in them.
  • Stick the smooth rod through the bearrings

print_settings.Notes:: I print in pla.  The main body, lever arm and cover should be printed laying flat so that no supports are needed (dont print with supports).  The key holster should be oriented so the slot is facing up so no support will be needed either.  the money clip should be printed separately, possibly with a raft because it needs to print standing up vertically in order to ensure that the clip has flexibility and wont break.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/phRK3Fs0ypw
This is one of the wallets that I sell. It's the Cardinal Wallet and i decided to share it. Because its a commercial product, I wont be able to remove the logo slot, however you can put anything you want there (the silver round thing) and i don't mind if you choose to sell it as well. It looks a little different from the one in the video and pictures because i edited it slightly since but the general design is the same. For the key, you'll need a small magnet (take a hammer and chisel 'carefully' to a ceramic magnet in necessary) and glue it into the main body. Also, you'll need to attach something metallic to the back of the key holster and obviously you'll have to file down your key. I used 2 small screws but anything metallic will do, as well as gluing it if necessary. It prints in 3 main parts (aside from the lever and key holster) so you will need to glue it. I recommend epoxy for the cover and contact cement (or epoxy) for the money clip, but really any adhesive of your choice. You can use a small washer or piece of rubber at the hinge if the arm wobbles but really it shouldnt ( nail works really well as a fulcrum for the hinge). What's important to prevent the cards from falling out is to get a really good quality thick rubber band and trim it to size as in the photo to allow it to work well. when the main body prints (without support) make sure the two 'arms' where the rubber bands will go are wobbling and flexing properly before assembling.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

Higher is better

Notes:

I print in pla. The main body, lever arm and cover should be printed laying flat so that no supports are needed (dont print with supports). The key holster should be oriented so the slot is facing up so no support will be needed either. the money clip should be printed separately, possibly with a raft because it needs to print standing up vertically in order to ensure that the clip has flexibility and wont break.

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/85SoOkxsDCt

Plinth Design Project

I've designed a plinth showcasing a melting glacier/icecap symbolizing both the significance and importance of the direct effects of global warming from a distance.

If this was placed in any public place, I think it would invoke conversation about it's implications- I think it would be even more revealing to add a penguin diving off of the glacier, or more detailed signs of ice melt

author: edelgreco

print_settings.Notes:: The models shown in the photos were all printed at 0.125mm or 0.15mm layer height, 0.3mm line width (out of a 0.4mm nozzle), with 5 or 6 top perimeters, 4 bottom, 3 side, 25%-35% infill, and rafts and supports. Since I'm sacrificing stability and ease of printing for realism, expect to have at least a few failures before you get your settings tuned in; YMMV, especially so if you're printing at worse resolution/line width.

title: 1:100 Tank/Tank Turrets with Open Commander's Hatch (Flames of War)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of tanks/tank turrets with their commander's hatches open, remixed from m_bergman's great 1:100 Tank pack. They are designed to be as realistic as possible (given the scale) while still allowing for Flames of War (or similar scale) commander figures/busts/bits/whateveryouwanttocallthem to fit in them.

Current turrets/tanks available are as follows:

United States:
M4 Sherman (late) w/ M3 75mm gun
M4A3 Sherman w/ M1 76mm gun
M4A3E8 "Easy Eight" Sherman w/ M1 76mm gun
M4A3 Sherman w/ M4 105mm howitzer/assault gun
M5A1 Stuart (late) with protective shield/deflector for the .30 cal MG

  • Figures used in pics for the above turrets are from the "USO198 Plastic American Tank Commander sprue" (available from the FoW online store)

Soviets:
T-34/85 obr 1944 (NOTE: since only half the cupola only opens up on this style of turret, fitting a commander figure into the opening may not work; I don't have any Soviet FoW commanders to test with. I'm working on a printable commander, but...yeah. Wish me luck with that, because so far I am seriously lacking in it. :-/ )

I will be updating this with new tanks/turrets as I design them for personal need. If anyone has specific requests, please feel free to contact me via the comments or PM with suggestions and I'll put it on my Things To Do With What Little Free Time I Have (As if I don't tell myself that the day before I start any new project, so it's somewhat of a meaningless statement at this point... ;) )

(Note: The M2HB .50 cal machinegun mounted on the Sherman turrets is located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1447064)

Printer:

Fabrikator Mini v1.5 and Wombot Exilis XL (mostly the Fab Mini)

Yes

Yes

0.15mm or better is strongly suggested

25%-35%

The models shown in the photos were all printed at 0.125mm or 0.15mm layer height, 0.3mm line width (out of a 0.4mm nozzle), with 5 or 6 top perimeters, 4 bottom, 3 side, 25%-35% infill, and rafts and supports. Since I'm sacrificing stability and ease of printing for realism, expect to have at least a few failures before you get your settings tuned in; YMMV, especially so if you're printing at worse resolution/line width.
05/16/2016 - Added T-34/85 obr 1944 turret with open hatch

description.text:
I'm scared to death that my printer is going to explode and burn my house down while I sleep.

I've read that these little firestop guys are a good form of protection, but I didn't really have anywhere to hang it above my printer except for maybe below a shelf... so I created a little hanger specifically designed to hold a firestop canister, and clip into a 2" thick shelf.

Printer:

Monoprice Dual Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20 or whatever you like

Infill:

50% +

Notes:

You might be able to get away without printing supports if you print this on its "back", but I felt like it would be more structurally sound if it was printed on its side, so I have a support in there between the two "teeth" that wrap around the pin.

No post printing steps needed other than to remove any supports you've added. The magnetic disc on the firestop canister fits snugly into the groove in the bottom plate. Then hang it wherever you have a shelf.

Hi This is a fan nozzle for the K8200 cooling fan. Just print and clip on the fan.
The air flow rate is much better than in the nozzle of the Velleman offers for download. It is my first own design. Quick and dirty.......

Just print it 1:1.
I printed without support or raft or brim.
Infill at 100% Enjoy

title: Robo3D R1 Hobbed bolt Idler for E3D v6 upgrade

description.text: This is a replacement for the bearing that tensions the material against the hobbed bolt. I upgraded to an E3D v6 hot end and I am using a full length PTFE tube (notched for the hobbed bolt but sticks up 1.5" above the top of the extruder), and the tube was getting deformed by the bearings flat surface when I would change materials. The radius cut in the replacement still applies tension to the PTFE and filament, but doesnt deform the PTFE and create unwanted friction

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

25%

Notes:

The center hole may be a bit snug on the bolt, depending on your tolerances, just ream with a drill bit if necessary.

author: NorCAL3D

description.text:
The dryer vent flap is used on a standard dryer exhaust vent on the exterior of a house. The exhaust from the dryer makes the flap open and when there is no exhaust the flap will fall back to cover the exhaust housing.

I have added a V2 of the vent that is easier to print. It is very close to the original but has a flat edge.

The PLA version I printed lasted about a year. It became very brittle due to the heat and elements. The last one I printed for a neighbor using the taulman bridge filament at 255c with a bed temp of 40c using a raft and printing on blue painters tape covered with elmers glue stick, it worked great and this filament is strong as hell. I like how the filament is somewhat flexible and very indestructible, I expect it to hold up very well for this application!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
Shows the type of dryer vent this flap is a replacement for, simply snaps in
Designed with Fusion 360

A Lotus Flower!

I added layers upon layers of circles to create a flower. Second, I extruded the certain ones to emphasize the flower in the center and the petals around it. A Art project for class and would look good on a desk.

Step 1

I added a circle in the midpoint.

Step 2

I added more circle surrounding the circle in the center. It should create a flower in the center.

Step 3

It should look like you are creating a flower in the center.

Step 4

I extruded the petals in the middle high enough to make the flower noticeable.

Step 5

I excluded the rest enough to create petals. Each just slightly extruded from the next to make it look like a flower resting on petals.

Step 6

I converted it to a stl file and fixed it on Meshlab

These parts, put together, will construct a small project frame out of 3/4in 1/16inwall Square Tubes. This Can be used to start contruction on many machines, including 3d printers. This update, 10/6/2013, is work on the Nema Mounts for the z axis. Not Fully Completed Yet, but soon be placed in to the design shortly. The openscad file does reflect this. Also, to use the file correctly you must download this file as well:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84339
by
http://www.thingiverse.com/MarkBenson/designs Well, more structure has been added today,9/28/2013.the openscad file is moving qickly along. as of 9/25/2013 I placed the openscad file up, as this is still a work in progress, and looking for sugestions. One is the liner riser bearing that is being use to stablize the platform. trying to target the holders so that the practical end result design will give all required parts. If you didn't understand that then look at what parts are missing, and you know where I am standing on the project. As of 9/18/2013 I decided that I would not be making a mendal printer because of a simple matter of moving mass that you are printing. I am sorry if you disagree, or otherwise want to comment on this thought, but I am sure that some degree of change does happen on prints when you are changing the mass on such a critical part of the devices operation. Also I added the deviders on top to accomidate a X and Y printhead on top. I am still going to use to motors for the Z, but that will be the tray holder.
Right now, as of 9/17/2013, I only have an outer frame  design of this project. Hoping to finish this design quickly to get it in to testing.

author: WICK12345

description.text:
OpenForge 2.0

This is a corridor for the external wall cut-stone series for OpenForge. Read up on the changes I've made in how I do tiles where the wall doesn't sit on the squares.

If you don't want to use the new attachable base, full tiles with bases attached are also uploaded with the name *.full_base.stl

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Instructions

For assembly instructions, painting videos and other extra information, see the instructions on the cut-stone wall.

How to use External Tiles

For instructions on the best way to use external tiles, see the guide on the cut-stone external wall

author: alexschreyer

description.text:
This is a wall mount for the Vive head mounted display (HMD). It was designed to support the Vive on its hard plastic parts to protect the soft foam from too much compression. It fits both the narrow and wide face cushion with any IPD and face distance setting.
The small triangle shaped compartment allows you to store your cleaning cloth or other accessories and it also saves some material during prints.

There is a new smaller version available that should make the model printable on more printers. (135mm x 116mm x 147mm)

Make sure that this mount is screwed to the wall very well and ensure that no one can step on the Vive's cable to avoid damage to your HMD. I am not responsible for any damage that this mount may do to your HMD.

author: nickbacich

description.text:
Second choice for 3D printing during our second class - "Let's Make a Part"

It's just a rough artistic sketch in onshape.
Balancing Gnome is my entry into the Gnome Remix challenge.  My goal is for it to return upright when pushed over. Let me know if it works for you.
I have not printed this yet, so I'm not sure if it will print (but it should). If I need to fix anything then I will update this asap. Please let me know if you have any trouble.

Print top at default medium setting in Makerware.
Print bottom at medium setting with 80% infill to add some weight to the base.

La stampante 3D "SeraMaker" è un progetto completo basato sulla "Prusa Mendel" di RepRap. I punti di forza sono le dimensioni del volume di stampa (20x20x20cm), l'estetica ispirata a MakerBot e, soprattutto, il sistema di espulsione dei fumi rilasciati dalla fusione della plastica.

Qui trovi diversi file utili alla realizzazione del progetto:
1) I modelli 3D per stampare i componenti plastici necessari all'assemblaggio. Il numero di copie per ciascuno, se diverso da 1, è specificato alla fine del nome.
2) Il firmware "Marlin" preconfigurato da caricare sull'unità di controllo Arduino.
3) PDF contenente l'elenco dei materiali per la realizzazione.
4) PDF contenente i disegni con le misure per la lavorazione dei pezzi che compongono la struttura.

Ulteriori dettagli sull'assemblaggio, il collegamento e la configurazione del progetto sono disponibili alla pagina e al video dedicato:

Sito web del progetto:
http://www.sebastianoserafini.it/progetti/stampante-3d-seramaker/

Video dedicato:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LIPi5zecKTQ
Miles Tails Prower Flying

print_settings.Notes:: Printed using mostly the default "fast" setting in Simplify3d (except I changed the external fill pattern to concentric because I thought it would look better with this pattern).  It printed in about 25 minutes.

description.text: A Victorian looking frame with a sheep inside.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

No

Notes:

Printed using mostly the default "fast" setting in Simplify3d (except I changed the external fill pattern to concentric because I thought it would look better with this pattern). It printed in about 25 minutes.
Thread some thread through the hole in the frame and the hole in the sheep and knot... then the sheep dangles. You can prop this up as a home decor type item or glue/tape it to the front of a card.
I designed it in Photoshop

title: DEPRECATED - B3 Innovations Pico Extruder upper fan shroud with capacitive proximity sensor mount for Type A Machines 2014 Series 1 (G1) v2

description.text:
DEPRECATED: I have designed a new ABL sensor mount that is more universal for Type A Machines Series 1 printers and posted the new "thingy" here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1736589
I have also designed a better B3 Innovations Pico fan shroud system for the Type A Machines Series 1 printers which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1477168

For archival purposes: Re-designed my upper fan shroud for the B3 Innovations Pico extruder to include a mount for a capacitive sensor (LJC18A3-H-Z/BX), and am now testing the sensor's abilities in combination with Marlin firmware modifications. This sensor is capable of detecting the glass/PEI print bed currently installed in my printer. I wired this sensor through the Series 1's PCB's and ribbon cable to keep things as clean as possible. Might be updating the design to level out the sensor a bit more, but it seems to work well, even at a bit of an angle (in comparison to the bed).

Video of my current print startup gcode: https://youtu.be/7s9vupOJpnU

Thanks +Thomas Sanladerer for your video (https://youtu.be/EcGFLwj0pnA) which I referenced while installing my bed sensor!

Sensor I used here on Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/uxcell-1-10mm-Capacitance-Proximity-Sensor/dp/B00542U3M4

5-15-16 Updated Upper_Shroud_6.1.stl. Made slight adjustment to the angle of the sensor mount. Although I am yet to test it, it should come out much more level than the initial release... Just printed and tested it; Still not quite level, but definitely much closer. Might come back to try to perfect this aspect of the design, but it totally serves it's purpose as-is.

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

2014 Series 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

ABS Used

Overall this 3D creation model was the hardest to create because of a two reasons. The two reasons why it was harder to create the 3D model was because from artist block, which limited my creativity; plus trials and errors to see if the design would be effective. Even though I used the 3D program SketchUp Pro 2015; modifying the creation to have a different use was harder to apply. At first it was unclear as to how it would assemble as a flower inspired lamp from the starting point, which was a spear head, but eventually I found the solution and it became a great success in design. Again for this creation as well I decided not to print it because from the lack of time.

For this 3D creation I designed it in multiple steps, which concluded to the final desired product. I first exported the spear head file created by Bitsandpieces3dprinting from Thingiverse. Then inputed the file into the 3D program SketchUp Pro 2015. Next I used the option box that contains different shapes to create squares below the spear head and then attaching the shape to it. After that i extruded the shape with the extrude option box to create the long spear shaft along with drawing a circle shape on the bottom of the spare shaft as a support base. Then I attached the circle shape to the spear shaft and extruded it to a proper size. Following that step then I drew a platform structure surrounding the bottom parts of the arrow points. Afterwards I started to fiddle around by using extrude and voilà as a result i got the structure, which was the flower petals. Following that step I extruded the square shapes in multiple directions to cause it to envelope the spear head in order to resemble a flower. Lastly, I added pentagon shape type holes to give it texture by drawing pentagon shapes into the extruded squares and then extruded the pentagons shapes inward.

It is made up of three parts that was somwone idee and I put them together in one file,
I think it will make fiilng 2 liter bottle with dry stuff easy
build and have fun

A configurable motor mounting bracket/firewall for attaching electric motors to Remote Controlled aeroplanes and so on. It was designed to allow easy attachment using hot-glue, cable ties or fixing screws -- or all of the above if you're really paranoid -- as well as provide some post print adjustment so long as you don't use glue.

The cut-out in the side wall of the bracket is intended to allow routing of your cables to the speed controller.

Overview of the Customizer here:
https://youtu.be/0iGzIrlrFR8

Find the channel here to subscribe:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5O1yJryrMbYm3xFmEhojFA

The included STL files are examples I built based on an EMAX 2204 2300KV motor. V2 XYZ: 30x30x30mm. V4 XYZ: 40x30x30mm (also slightly longer slide retaining holes)

UPDATE -- 28/04/2016
Added the ability to specify a separate X value (length) to allow greater length without the need to increase the surface area of the motor mount.

description.text: This is a relocation mount specifically designed for my Arduino Project Box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1520159) but it could be used to hang other things as well. This item was designed to relocate the Project Box to the right side of the printer instead of being locked into the left side. It also gives the ability to use two of the project boxes on one printer if desired. The mount isn't specific to be mounted on the right or left side of the printer so it could be universally used for anything that will mount to it. It is strong and fits my QIDI Tech perfectly; I'm sure it could be used for Flashforge printers as well. In one picture you can see I tested it with my utility bin.

title: GoPro Hero 3 Steady Cam Concept
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.header: A hand held or base mounted steady cam for the GoPro Hero 3.
description.text:
This is unusual because it is servo/motor free and there is no counter balance underslung weight either. The vibrations and pitch/roll are dampened out by the use of an overhead pot, filled with a suitable easily sourced medium (see instructions). Originally designed for mounting onto my DJI 450 Quadcopter, however with the addition of the clip in handle (removable), it becomes a hand held steady cam too. I designed and printed this as a proof of concept. I wanted to push further the idea of a print in place assembly for the main body component, and to inspire. EDIT 15/05/2014 : Uploaded STEP file of the assembly, in case anyone wants to make any edits. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Add an M5 x 40 screw and nut. Everything except the "Waggle Stick Clamp" can be printed without support. However the handle may benefit from support due to the fillets for grip comfort. GoPro_Gimbal_Mount_Base.stl has two bits of support modelled for the holes at the base of the pot which can easily be removed with a craft knife. Seems a bit "notchy" at first but it does bed in and become smoother over time. I'm sure a bearing version would be super smooth. A little olive oil helps too. Fill the pot to suitable height with suitable medium, bit of trial and error for this one, eg :
  • Polystyrene beads
  • Necklace beads
  • Plastic ball bearings
  • Pasta balls
  • Memory foam

• 1 x GoPro_Gimbal_Mount_Base.stl
  • 1 x GoPro_Waggle_Stick_Clamp.stl (100% infill)
  • 1 x Seal.stl
  • 2 x GoPro_Hero_3_Bump_Guard.stl (100% infill)
  • 2 x Bush.stl

• 1 x Handle.stl
  • 2 x Pin.stl

title: 6mm OD PTFE Teflon Filament Tube Coupler / Joiner

description.text: This is a 6mm OD PTFE/Teflon filament tube coupler / joiner I designed that does just that - joins two pieces of 6mm OD filament tube together. The filament tubes press fit into the coupler and should fit quite snug without deformation. The tubes insert ~12-14mm into each side for a good fit. This is a set of tools to check either a radius or a diameter. The hooked end has the labeled radius on the inner and outer edge. The round end has the labeled diameter hole and the labeled radius outer edge.
For example if the hooked end has a 5 printed on it, the inside curve has a radius of 5mm, the outside curve has a 5mm radius. If the end with a hole has a 10 printed on it, then the hole is 10mm diameter, and the outer edge is 10mm radius. All have a 5mm hole in the center, and a small tick mark to identify the start/end of the curve. Gauges for both inch and metric: 1mm-26mm radius (1mm increments), and 1/16"-1" radius (1/16" increments). Thank you for your input:
Mr. Smout: http://www.thingiverse.com/Smoutech/overview
asmacdo: http://www.thingiverse.com/asmacdo/overview

Tablet slides in on top - connecting the HDMI and USB ports. Cut-outs for speakers, earphone jack and power/volume buttons. Battery is exchangeable 8400 mAh. Solar panel is detachable and can be flipped  180° for protection. Side and top panels (top is not shown on the 'thing') lock in by strong neodymium magnets. Still need fine tuning: external power connectors and HDMI out and USB in.

Tic Tac Box Maze Game inspired by DesignMakeTeach's Tic Tac Box Challenge.(thing:1478956)
Works perfectly with a 4 mm ball.

Printer:

Other

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

10%

The maze was designed from an online random maze generator (2-D) and the walls were modified in a drawing program. It was then converted to 3-D in Inkscape using mathgrrl's method shown here (http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2013/12/day-109-sharpie-print.html).
From there, Tinkercad was used to optimize the size of the fit of the maze to the box (using the tic_tac_inside_dimensions stl file) and to add the cap with the holes for the ball.

2-D Maze Generator: (http://puzzlemaker.discoveryeducation.com/AdvMazeSetupForm.asp)
Settings to get correct maze dimensions
Width (7) Height (12) Additional (5)
Number of pixels per square: 30

comments.text: Please make more / different designs, this one is so addicting to play with. Great job, and good fit.
comments.author: agent1113

comments.text: here's an idea... based on a similar maze we made in school with a CNC milling machine... when the printer prints the floor, change filament colour so the walls are a different colour :D depends what printer you have, mines a wanhao so you can cut the filament at the head and feed a new colour on top... :) so you get a black maze with red walls for example :)

description.text: These are simple caps designed to seal off the open filament ports on this filament dry box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961881).
